Mike Woodhouse wrote:

>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, ej <e.j@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>By 'normalised' what I mean is this....
>>Get the last N days. Get the highest high and the lowest low over the 
>>period.
>>Rescale all the data so that the lowest low is -1 and the highest high 
>>is +1 then present the normalised high, low, open, close and volume 
>>(normalised with max volume over period=1, lowest =0) as inputs.
>>    
>>
>
>
>While I believe it's absolutely essential to transform input data, I'm
>not a huge fan of this type of normalisation, which tends to compress
>the bulk of the trading range into too small an interval in order to
>accommodate the occasional outliers. The arbitrary restriction to a
>[-1,1] interval is potentially restricting, too.
>
>I'd suggest it might be worth your while looking at using "standard"
>or "Z" scores (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_score) and
>using the daily return (price today / price yesterday) as the value.
>The Z-score then restates each movement as a number of standard
>deviations away from the mean, which (a) lets the outliers take really
>large values without over-compressing the more mundane values and (b)
>removes trend information.
>
>Just a thought...
>
>  
>

Hi Mike, Emyr, All

This definitely seems to be the most sound approach to take to me. It 
does introduce the problem of having to calculate (sample) the mean and 
standard deviation from a sample set of data which, as I was saying 
before, you should then avoid for training and testing purposes - which 
is a problem if, like me, you already have limited data.

Currently I'm using the daily percentage change in price as an input 
signal as you suggested, but I use the raw figure as it's typically  
within the range -1 to 1 anyway (in fact more like +-0.1 of course), 
with the occasional outlying figure which could be anywhere from +-0.5 
to +3. Using the number of standard deviations would generate a similar 
number for these outlying cases, instead of the rather arbitrary number 
that would get used (input to an ANN) otherwise.

For volume and # of trades Z-scores are even more appropriate since we 
cannot really use daily percentage change for these signals because they 
can change by such large amount from day to day. E.g. you might have a 
quiet trading day with a few thousand shares traded and several million 
traded the next day due to some news/event. Currently I use 
log10(volume) to generate a signal appropriate for feeding into an ANN, 
but on reflection a Z-score is a far more mathematically sound choice.

Regards,

Colin
